title: Core Task Management System
description:
Build the foundational task management functionality that allows developers to create, update, list, and delete tasks with priority and status tracking.

**Context:**
- **Business Context:** Developers need fast, frictionless task management that doesn't interrupt their terminal-based workflow
- **Target Users:** Software developers who live in the terminal and want sub-100ms task operations
- **Brand Voice:** Minimal, fast, developer-focused - prioritizing speed and simplicity over complexity
- **Success Metrics:** All CRUD operations complete in <100ms, intuitive command structure, zero learning curve for terminal users

**Testing Requirements:**
- **Unit Tests:** Test task CRUD operations, JSON serialization/deserialization, priority and status validation
- **Integration Tests:** Test CLI commands end-to-end, file system operations, data persistence
- **Type Tests:** Validate Go struct definitions, JSON schema compliance, input validation
- **E2E Tests:** Test complete user workflows: create→update→list→delete task sequences
acceptance_criteria:
- Tasks can be created with title, description, and priority in a single command
- Task status can be updated (todo, in-progress, done) with simple commands
- Tasks can be listed with filtering by status and priority
- Tasks can be deleted individually
- All operations complete in under 100ms
- Data persists locally in JSON format

title: Implement Task Data Model and Storage
description:
Create Go structs for task representation and implement JSON-based local storage with file system operations.

**Context:**
- **Business Context:** Developers need reliable offline task storage without external dependencies - critical for productivity during network outages or when working in restricted environments
- **Target Users:** Developers who work offline or in environments with limited connectivity
- **Brand Voice:** Simple, reliable, zero-config - works out of the box
- **Success Metrics:** Tasks persist reliably, config directory auto-created, JSON format human-readable for debugging

**Testing Requirements:**
- **Unit Tests:** Task struct validation, JSON marshaling/unmarshaling, file operations, ID generation
- **Integration Tests:** Full storage layer integration, concurrent access handling, error recovery
- **Type Tests:** Go struct tags validation, JSON schema compliance, data type constraints
design: Use standard Go encoding/json package for serialization. Store tasks in ~/.taskman/tasks.json with atomic write operations to prevent corruption. Include task ID generation using UUIDs or incremental integers.

title: Define Task struct with JSON tags
description:
Create core Task struct with ID, Title, Description, Priority, Status, CreatedAt, UpdatedAt fields and appropriate JSON serialization tags.

**Context:** For developers who need fast task CRUD - struct must be optimized for performance and include all fields needed for filtering and sorting. JSON tags ensure clean API.

**Testing Requirements:**
- **Unit Tests:** Struct field validation, JSON tag correctness, default value handling
- **Type Tests:** Go struct compilation, JSON schema validation, field constraints

title: Implement JSON file storage operations
description:
Create functions for reading and writing task lists to ~/.taskman/tasks.json with atomic operations and error handling.

**Context:** For developers working offline - storage must be bulletproof with atomic writes to prevent data corruption during unexpected shutdowns or system crashes.

**Testing Requirements:**
- **Unit Tests:** File read/write operations, atomic write implementation, error handling paths
- **Integration Tests:** Full file system integration, concurrent access scenarios, corruption recovery
- **Type Tests:** File permission validation, path handling, JSON format validation

title: Build CLI Interface and Commands
description:
Implement command-line interface using Go's flag package or Cobra for task creation, listing, updating, and deletion with intuitive syntax.

**Context:**
- **Business Context:** Developer productivity depends on frictionless CLI with muscle-memory commands - must feel natural to terminal users and integrate seamlessly into existing workflows
- **Target Users:** Developers who use git, make, docker and other CLI tools daily
- **Brand Voice:** Intuitive, consistent with Unix philosophy, follows CLI conventions
- **Success Metrics:** Commands are memorable, help text is clear, follows standard CLI patterns (-h, --help, consistent flag naming)

**Testing Requirements:**
- **Unit Tests:** Command parsing, flag validation, help text generation, command routing
- **Integration Tests:** Full CLI command execution, argument parsing, output formatting
- **Type Tests:** Command line argument validation, flag type checking
- **E2E Tests:** Complete user command workflows from terminal
design: Use standard Go flag package or consider Cobra for subcommands. Commands should follow patterns: 'task create', 'task list', 'task update', 'task delete'. Include short and long flag options.

title: Implement task creation command
description:
Create 'task create' command that accepts title, description, and priority flags and creates a new task with validation.

**Context:** For busy developers - task creation must be fast (<100ms) and accept all required info in one command to minimize workflow interruption.

**Testing Requirements:**
- **Unit Tests:** Command argument parsing, task validation, success/error responses
- **Integration Tests:** End-to-end task creation including persistence
- **Type Tests:** Input validation, flag parsing, command registration
- **E2E Tests:** Full command execution from shell

title: Implement task listing and filtering commands
description:
Create 'task list' command with filtering options by status and priority, including formatted output for readability.

**Context:** For developers managing multiple tasks - list output must be scannable and filterable to quickly find relevant work. Support common developer filtering patterns.

**Testing Requirements:**
- **Unit Tests:** Filtering logic, output formatting, sort ordering
- **Integration Tests:** Full list command with various filter combinations
- **Type Tests:** Filter parameter validation, output format validation
- **E2E Tests:** Complete filtering workflows from command line
